

Whiplash
aaaa
2015 / From Now / Cert PG
full metal drum kit

During an audience Q&A at the Toronto Film Festival, which is included as an extra on Whiplash’s Blu-ray, first-time director Damien Chazelle was asked what drove him to switch careers from jazz drummer to filmmaker. His answer is meant as a half-joke — isn’t it obvious? — but you can detect an edge to his tone: “Everything that’s in the film.”

Whiplash is one of 2014’s finest movies, and home to an Oscar-winning performance from beloved character actor J. K. Simmons (aka Juno’s dad). Above all, it is a personal piece, and all the better for it. Chazelle’s bloody, sweaty, teary experience drenches every frame and gives his characters such compelling, convincing life that you don’t even need to be eased into their arcane musical existence. Without a single expository spoon-serving, you’re plunged straight into the oblique world of jazz, and even those usually repelled by the J-word will be guaranteed as satisfying an experience as those raised on the teat of Buddy Rich.

Its resounding critical success is proof of this. But also of the proficiency and chemistry of its two lead actors. Simmons, with his soft, bloodhound features, is usually cast in fuzzy and affable roles — frequently by Jason Reitman, also uncoincidentally Chazelle’s mentor and one of the film’s executive producers. But here in the role of jazz conductor Fletcher, the bloodhound plays pitbull. The band leader as drill sergeant, Fletcher is a bully of such intense and reprehensible monstrosity that he becomes antiheroic. It’s enough of a departure from Simmons’ usual work (at least since he appeared in HBO’s brutal prison drama Oz) that when his honeyed, sonorous tones waft over the film’s commentary track, you can’t help but wonder if on set Chazelle somehow summoned his evil twin from the Dark Dimension.

Simmons, though, is not the film’s heart. As stick-wielding prodigy Andrew Nieman, Miles Teller marks himself out as an acting force to be reckoned with, both a remarkable technician (yes, he’s really drumming) and a chameleon, fluidly realising Andrew’s transformation from keen student to volatile and sometimes cruelly ambitious obsessive. Genius takes its toll — that’s the tale’s more obvious moral. But its strengths are really found where its ambiguity lies. Andrew and Fletcher are simultaneously mentor/pupil and bitter enemies. Come the climax, it almost resembles a sports movie, with the viewer left unsure as to which competitor has actually won. Is the triumph Andrew’s? Or is it really Fletcher’s? “To me,” notes Simmons on the commentary, “it was win-win [for Fletcher].” We suspect Teller (whose absence in the recording booth is the source of much mirth) would disagree. Chazelle stays schtum.

LIKE THIS, WATCH THIS

THE COLOR OF MONEY 1986 Martin Scorsese’s sequel to The Hustler has another uneasy student/teacher dynamic (and sticks of a different kind) as Paul Newman’s pool hustler coaches Tom Cruise.

Which brings us back to the director’s half-joke about the reason he quit jazz drumming. Perhaps the teacher whose questionable methods sent him packing remains a huge villain in his life. Then again, if he hadn’t been driven away, he may not have made this film, and achieved this truly astonishing breakthrough. It’s clear Chazelle senses that, in a perverse way, he owes this person, despite all the abuse they heaped on him. And so do we — not least giving us the phrase, “Are you a rusher, or are you a dragger?” We’d say, “Good job,” but... DJ
